titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Dutch colonial houses photographic negatives V1974.043
titlestmt.author: Patricia Glowinski
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-21 11:19:23 +0000.

physdesc.extent: 105 photographic negatives and four contact sheets housed in one medium negatives box and one folder.

did.abstract: The Dutch colonial houses photographic negatives consist of 105 black-and-white photographic negatives and four contact sheets depicting Dutch colonial houses, presumably located in Brooklyn. The photographer is unknown.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: Dutch colonial houses were built in Brooklyn by early Dutch settlers and their descendants to resemble the architecture of the Netherlands. Dutch colonial houses in Brooklyn are identifiable by their gambrel roofs (typically a symmetrical two-sided roof consisting of two slopes), curved projecting eaves, end chimneys, shingled siding, and south facing entrances. As of 2011, several examples of Dutch colonial houses remain in Brooklyn, including the Hendrick I. Lott House located at 1940 East 36th Street in the Marine Park neighborhood, the Pieter Lefferts House now located in Prospect Park (originally located on Flatbush Avenue near Maple Street in what today would be the Prospect Lefferts Garden neighborhood), and the Pieter Claeson Wyckoff House located at 5816 Clarendon Road at Ralph Avenue in the neighborhood of East Flatbush. All houses are landmarked, while the Wyckoff house holds the distinction as the first building in New York City to be landmarked.

list.head: Sources:
list.item: Neighborhood Preservation Center. "New York City Landmark Preservation Commission Designation Reports: Hendrick I. Lott House." Accessed June 16, 2011. http://www.neighborhoodpreservationcenter.org/db/bb_files/89-LOTT-HOUSE.pdf
The Wyckoff House and Association. "History." Accessed June 16, 2011. http://www.wyckoffassociation.org/association/history.html
Dilliard, Maud Esther. Old Dutch Houses of Brooklyn. New York: R. R. Smith, 1945.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Dutch colonial houses photographic negatives consist of 105 black-and-white photographic negatives and four contact sheets depicting Dutch colonial houses, presumably located in Brooklyn. The photographer is unknown.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Brooklyn Historical Society also holds several related collections. Interested researchers should see the Adrian Vanderveer Martense collection (ARC.191); John Jay Pierrepont photograph collection (ARC.197); Dutch in New York lantern slide collection (V1974.025); Dutch Homesteads exhibit photograph collection (V1974.035); Steven W. Giles glass plate negatives and other photographic material (V1980.001); Abbot Low Moffat collection of Brooklyn photography (V1980.003); Ralph Irving Lloyd lantern slides (V1981.015); and the Joseph V. Lieber photographs of Dutch colonial houses in Brooklyn (V1974.042). Please consult library staff for more information.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Fully processed to the item level.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Dutch colonial houses photographic negatives, V1974.043, Box number, Object ID number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids
otherfindaid.p: Item level description and digital versions of images from the collection are available for searching via the image database in the library. Please consult library staff for more information.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition for this collection are unknown. The collection was formally accessioned in 1974.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright for anonymously created items remain in effect for 120 years following the date of creation. Based on the date range of this collection, the photographic negatives will enter the public domain in 2100. For information on securing rights to publish or reproduce, please see the Brooklyn Historical Society Reproduction Rights Policy.
